articles.headline: Abductions Hurt U.S. Bid to Train Anti-ISIS Rebels in Syria
articles.snippet: A troubled Pentagon program to train Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has produced only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.
articles.abstract: A troubled Pentagon program to train Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has produced only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — A Pentagon program to train moderate Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has been vexed by problems of recruitment, screening, dismissals and desertions that have left only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.
articles.byline: By Karam Shoumali, Anne Barnard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: U.S. Psychologists Urged to Curb Questioning Terror Suspects
articles.snippet: The proposal came after a report that members colluded with the Pentagon and the C.I.A. in justifying harsh questioning of terrorism suspects during the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: The proposal came after a report that members colluded with the Pentagon and the C.I.A. in justifying harsh questioning of terrorism suspects during the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The board of the American Psychological Association plans to recommend a tough ethics policy that would prohibit psychologists from involvement in all national security interrogations, potentially creating a new obstacle to the Obama administration’s efforts to detain and interrogate terrorism suspects outside of the traditional criminal justice system.

articles.headline: Bailout Money Goes to Greece, Only to Flow Out Again
articles.snippet: Instead of going into the economy, the funding Greece has received has largely allowed Greeks and foreign investors to get their money out.
articles.abstract: Instead of going into the economy, the funding Greece has received has largely allowed Greeks and foreign investors to get their money out.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The Greek businessman was nervous as he carried a suitcase stuffed with cash through security at the Athens airport a few months ago. But the distracted and overworked officials waved him through.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: In Microsoft’s Nokia Debacle, a View of an Industry’s Feet of Clay
articles.snippet: The technology business is especially vulnerable to rapid, unforeseen transformation, sometimes leading to the mass extinction of giant companies.
articles.abstract: The technology business is especially vulnerable to rapid, unforeseen transformation, sometimes leading to the mass extinction of giant companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s call it the $7.5 billion lesson.

articles.headline: How a Chinese Billionaire Built Her Fortune
articles.snippet: Zhou Qunfei, founder of Lens Technology, has come to define a new class of female entrepreneurs in China who have built their wealth from scratch.
articles.abstract: Zhou Qunfei, founder of Lens Technology, has come to define a new class of female entrepreneurs in China who have built their wealth from scratch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zhou Qunfei is the world’s richest self-made woman. Ms. Zhou, the founder of Lens Technology, owns a $27 million estate in Hong Kong. She jets off to Silicon Valley and Seoul, South Korea, to court executives at Apple and Samsung, her two biggest customers. She has played host to President Xi Jinping of China, when he visited her company’s headquarters.

articles.headline: Banking for Pot Industry Hits a Roadblock
articles.snippet: After its application to serve the marijuana business was denied, a credit union filed a lawsuit demanding “equal access” to the financial system.
articles.abstract: After its application to serve the marijuana business was denied, a credit union filed a lawsuit demanding “equal access” to the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banking regulators just said no to a financial institution that aims to be the first to serve the expanding marijuana industry in Colorado.

articles.headline: Glare of Video Is Shifting Public’s View of Police
articles.snippet: The recording of encounters between the police and the public has begun to alter public views of the use of force and race relations, experts and police officials say.
articles.abstract: The recording of encounters between the police and the public has begun to alter public views of the use of force and race relations, experts and police officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: They began as workaday interactions between the police and the public, often involving minor traffic stops in places like Cincinnati; North Charleston, S.C.; and Waller County, Tex. But they swiftly escalated into violent encounters. And all were captured on video.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Koch Brothers Brave Spotlight to Try to Alter Their Image
articles.snippet: After two elections in which liberals sought to cast them as the secretive face of the G.O.P., the billionaire brothers want to change perceptions of their family.
articles.abstract: After two elections in which liberals sought to cast them as the secretive face of the G.O.P., the billionaire brothers want to change perceptions of their family.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once known for grim letters to fellow wealthy Americans warning of socialist apocalypse, Charles G. Koch now promotes research on the link between freedom and everyday happiness. Turn on “The Big Bang Theory” or “Morning Joe,” and you are likely to see soft-focus television spots introducing some of the many employees of Koch Industries.

articles.headline: A Slack Lifeline for Drowning Homeowners
articles.snippet: A report suggests that a program intended to help as many as four million troubled borrowers has allowed big banks to run roughshod over them again and again.
articles.abstract: A report suggests that a program intended to help as many as four million troubled borrowers has allowed big banks to run roughshod over them again and again.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Lucy Circe became disabled and could no longer work, she applied to Bank of America for a mortgage loan modification on her Vermont home. Over more than two years, starting in 2012, the bank repeatedly requested copies of documents that had already been provided, asked for proof that she was no longer married to a man she did not even know, and made other errors, like asking why Ms. Circe had indicated that she didn’t want to keep her property when she had actually told the bank she did.

articles.headline: Talks for Pacific Trade Deal Stumble
articles.snippet: The breakdown is a setback for the Obama administration, which had promoted the talks as the final round for the largest regional trade agreement ever.
articles.abstract: The breakdown is a setback for the Obama administration, which had promoted the talks as the final round for the largest regional trade agreement ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHAINA, Hawaii — Trade negotiators from the United States and 11 other Pacific nations failed to reach final agreement on Friday, with difficult talks on the largest regional trade agreement ever deadlocking over protections for drug companies and access to agriculture markets on both sides of the Pacific.
